entry.title: How to turn SAP workshop notes into clear and testable Requirements
entry.content:
During SAP Activateâ€™s Explore phase and the Fit-to-Standard workshops, consultants capture dozens of â€œrequirements,â€ each meant to articulate a specific business need. Without clear formulation standards, a few weeks later no one is quite sure what the original request actually meant. This undermines the workshopâ€™s primary goal: validating solution fit.

The real pain - inconsistency

In SAP programs, requirements that are vague or inconsistently written become a main source of unnecessarily lost effort. When two workstreams describe the same business need in different words, duplication multiply which may lead to unnecessary testing of the same functionality or cause change requests.

For example, when a requirement says â€œsystem should support automatic approvalâ€ no one will know what support actually meant when they discussed it during a workshop. You cannot test such a requirement later.

Ambiguity has measurable cost

Each unclear requirement multiplies into unnecessary discussions, rework, and test defects. Misunderstandings accumulate silently until they become visible during the first cycle of testing, when the system finally reveals whether the requirement was truly met.

The true risk of Requirements Management is not the absence of requirements documentation, but the lack of consistency in how requirements are formulated.

Not having the requirement formulation standards, which are recommended by SAP Activate, is one of the major sources of rework and wasted effort. When requirements are written in different formats and tones, they cannot be easily classified, compared, or reused.

Why clear formulation matters

SAP Activateâ€™s agile approach is built on the idea that requirements evolve. But they must be clear right from the start as the backlog entry, so that they can be reviewed, classified, and approved later. Clarity does not mean rigidity. It means writing requirements so they can be discussed, prioritized, tested, and traced - even as they may change later.

 A well formulated requirement contains four elements in one short sentence:

Who â€“ the role that needs the functionality
When â€“ the situation or trigger
What â€“ the action or system behavior
Why â€“ the intended business benefit

When these four parts are present, the requirement becomes verifiable. It can be confirmed during testing and explained during audit reviews. More importantly, it can be reused across teams and releases because it is self-contained and unambiguous.

The right format for SAP projects

SAPâ€™s Agile method proposes the familiar User Story format: â€œAs a [role], I want [feature], so that [business value].â€ In practice, this structure is often too generic for configuration and testing.

A better pattern for SAP requirements adds context and system behavior:

As [Role], when [Condition], the system will [Action] on [Object] so that [Benefit].

This sentence looks simple, but it solves three common problems:

1) It describes the trigger (when), which links to a real process step.
2) It defines the system reaction (will [Action]), which makes the behavior testable.
3) It keeps the business benefit explicit, which ties it back to value and approval.

This version includes all four elements: who, when, what, and why.
Anyone reading it should understands both the intent and the expected outcome.

Adding a â€œHow to Demoâ€ section

A practical way to make requirements even clearer is to include a short â€œHow to Demoâ€ note directly under the description. This is not a full test case but rather a quick outline of how someone would prove that the requirement works. This serves as a draft for formal test cases and ensures that requirements can be verified during Activateâ€™s test preparation phase.

This small â€œHow to demoâ€ section acts as an early test-case draft. It helps reviewers visualize expected behavior and gives testers a ready starting point for building the formal Test Case later. In larger projects, these demo notes become a lightweight bridge between requirement authoring and structured testing, keeping intent, behavior, and verification tightly connected.

Finding the right level of detail

A well-written requirement should guide the Realize phase. Too much detail turns it into a mini-functional specification; too little makes it meaningless. The right level of abstraction sits between business intention and technical configuration.

When many team members are involved in requirements formulation, duplication can easily occur. Similar needs appear in different modules, often under different wording. To prevent this, each requirement should reference its related SAP Best Practice Process represented by an approved Scope Item. This simple linking helps identify overlaps early and supports reuse across workstreams.

From quick notes to refined requirements

In line with SAP Activateâ€™s iterative principle, requirements may first be recorded in simple terms and refined later during backlog reviews and work package definition. What matters most in that moment is to capture the intent in a simplified form and then refine it later.

For example:
â€œAdd a process step for automatic credit check approval before delivery creation.â€ â†’ GAP

Such a note still has value. During later review, typically when preparing the related Work Package, the requirement can be reformulated to the full standard:

As a Sales Manager, when a sales order is saved and the customer exceeds the credit limit, the system will block delivery creation on the delivery document so that only approved orders can ship.

This two-step approach keeps workshops efficient while ensuring that every requirement ultimately meets the agreed structure before review, approval, and test preparation.

How to make this standard work in Jira?

Formulation discipline is easier to maintain when supported by a tool.
In Jira, you can create an automation rule that pre-populates the Description field of each new Requirement with a Activate-style structured template.

In the template, you can use a table to make the content easier to follow. Each author then only needs to fill in the blanks. This keeps every requirement standardized.

For simplicity, below the requirement you can add a simple list with the â€˜How to demoâ€™ steps.

Why itâ€™s worth the effort?

A requirement is not a transcript of a workshop discussion. It is a helpful SAP governance standard that supports the SAP delivery lifecycle.

Teams that adopt this standardization rule quickly notice tangible benefits:
-> Requirements become easier to review and approve.
-> Test cases can be linked directly and generated faster.
-> Cross-team understanding improves, because every sentence follows the same logic.

Formulation discipline may feel like a big effort, but it pays back throughout the project lifecycle. Clear requirements accelerate testing, improve governance, and reduce rework.

entry.title: How to build clarity in SAP Projects with Jira
entry.content:
Is it your day in SAP project life?

Your SAP project is in the middle of Fit-to-Standard analysis, your Requirements Backlog grows quickly, requirements are flowing in from all teams, but itâ€™s impossible to see what matters most or what type of work is hiding behind the summary and description.

If that sounds familiar, your project might be missing the structured requirement classification discipline recommended by SAP Activate. Without this approach, the requirements backlog turns into a flat list, where priorities will be hard to assign and some of the expected outcomes will not be properly documented.

With structured classification, it becomes clear what type of outcomes weâ€™re delivering and what kind of documentation and work is actually required. It enables credible estimation, release wave planning, and test coverage without the need to re-explain the project every week.

What is Requirement Classification?

Classification provides a structured way to label requirements so they can be grouped, prioritized, tracked, and reported consistently across both functional and technical workstreams.
Together with formulation standards, it keeps your requirements backlog clean and actionable for delivery and status reporting.

Every requirement should be labeled along two dimensions:

1ï¸) Level - hierarchy: shows where the requirement sits in the project - higher strategic level or lower detailed level.
2ï¸) Type - nature of work: signals what kind of effort is needed to deliver it.

The Dual Classification Model â€” Levels & Types

Levels hierarchy - reflects the â€œzoomâ€ level:
-> L1 â€“ High-Level Business Requirement: The â€œwhyâ€ - what business value or capability must be achieved.
-> L2 â€“ Process-Level Requirement: The â€œwhatâ€ - process activities or steps that bring the business outcome to life.
-> L3 â€“ Functional Requirement: The â€œhowâ€ - concrete system behaviors, validations, or interactions that enable the process step. At this level, SAP Activate recommends requirements be formulated so they are traceable and testable.

Types - nature of work - reflects the solution pathway:
-> FIT: Standard SAP functionality meets the need as is; adopt standard SAP.
-> GAP: Missing functionality requiring additional configuration or enhancement.
-> EXT (Extension / WRICEF): Technical work â€” interfaces, reports, conversions, enhancements, forms.
-> NFR (Non-Functional Requirement): Qualities such as performance, security, compliance, or usability.

Combine both dimensions and youâ€™ll see your full solution scope - how much fits standard SAP, which areas need only configuration, and where technical extensions or non-functional demands will influence delivery. This will help later with accurate effort estimation and release governance.

From Discover to Explore: how requirements detail changes

Discover Phase:
Requirements are collected as high-level outcomes or business goals mapped to solution scope. They are articulated as value drivers and not yet detailed as process or system requirements.
Prepare Phase:
Refined and agreed high level requirements are turned into scope statements and acceptance criteria. They become part of the project charter, forming the project baseline.
Explore Phase:
Time to dive in. Now, during the Fit-to-Standard workshops, the team validates which SAP Best Practices satisfy business needs (FIT), pinpoint deltas (GAP, EXT/WRICEF, NFR), and detail process-level or functional requirements for each business activity. The goal is not to restate strategic goals but to clarify how each is realized in process terms.

Requirements refinement example

Here is a quick example to demonstrate how the level of details changes between requirement levels. These changes are the result of iterations.

High Level (L1):
â€œEnsure that customer credit exposure is controlled during the order-to-cash process to minimize financial risk and enforce company credit policy.â€
Process Level (L2):
â€œAdd a process step to validate customer credit before order confirmation, ensuring that orders exceeding credit limits are identified and stopped before delivery or invoicing.â€
Functional Level (L3):
â€œAs a Sales Representative when a Sales Order is saved for a customer whose credit exposure exceeds their credit limit the system will automatically block the Sales Order and display a message indicating the credit limit breach so that financially non-compliant orders are prevented from further processing and company credit policy is enforced.â€
Depending on SAP coverage, requirement form this example could be a GAP (needs configuration) or an EXT (custom validation).

When a Level 3 requirement is formulated using an agreed template and properly classified, it becomes much easier to estimate the required effort and remains traceable from the very beginning all the way through deployment.

What about Non-Functional Requirements?

It may seem counterintuitive, but SAP methodologies - including Activate and Focused Build - classify most Non-Functional Requirements (NFRs) at the same (functional) level as detailed system requirements. While their name suggests they are â€œnon-functional,â€ they describe qualities that apply to specific system functions, such as performance, security, or usability. In practice, they sit at the same level of detail as functional requirements, because they can be specified, tested, and verified against system behavior.

For example:

â€œThe system shall process 10 000 purchase order lines within 60 seconds under normal load conditions.â€
â€œUser data shall be stored only within EU-based data centers.â€

 Bringing classification to practice in Jira

The flexibility of Jira allows you to capture more than just a requirementâ€™s name and description. You can also collect structured metadata for governance and reporting. You are not limited in customizations like in SAP native tools.

Possible Jira configuration:

  • Add custom fields to record key attributes such as Requirement Level (High-Level, Process-Level, Functional) and Requirement Type (FIT, GAP, EXT, NFR, etc.).

  • Configure these fields as drop-down lists so that users must select a defined value, ensuring consistent classification across all teams.

Standardized metadata enables filtering, reporting, and building reporting dashboards by type, level, or workstream, giving full transparency into project and solution scope composition.

Even that simple setup unlocks powerful reporting in Jira: dashboards showing % FIT coverage, distribution of GAPs and WRICEFs, or NFR readiness by release. Your backlog becomes a live dashboard, not a static list in Excel.

 

Whatâ€™s in it for you?

Just like requirement formulation standard discussed on SAP Community here, clarity is also about bringing structure and governance to Requirements Management. When every requirement has its place and type, governance stops being a reporting exercise and becomes a shared language. Classification is not overhead or project administration - it is the structure that keeps delivery, design, and testing aligned, supports compliance, and maintains clear documentation from the first workshop to go-live.

And the question
If I opened your requirements tracker today (I hope it is Jira) and picked five random requirements, would I instantly see what each one means, what type of work it implies, and where it fits in your process? If not, you know now what to do.

entry.title: Test Data Refresh: Enhancing test tenant quality
entry.content:
We have seen how data migration is supported during 3SL conversion in ourâ€¯Data Migration for Test Environment Validation in ... - SAP Communityâ€¯blog, we have also seen how Test Data Conversion (TDC) plays a vital role in accelerating the test tenant readiness with valid depersonalised test data and system configurations from Previous quality tenant in Test Data Conversion, the accelerator: scaling sma... - SAP Community blog.  

Building on that foundation, this blog focuses on the next topic, Test Data Refresh (TDR) in the 3SL post conversion journey. TDR is a strategic service offered by SAP to ensure the availability of high quality, production like test data in the test tenant for all the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition customers. Letâ€™s understand the purpose, value, and prerequisites of TDR, and realise how it enhances ongoing quality assurance and supports efficient testing environment. 

 

 TDR: Ongoing quality assurance: 

The TDR service is a subscription-based service with the flexibility of multi-use service designed to provide S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition customers with accurate, production-like data in their test tenant. It ensures that the test tenant reflects the latest application data from the production tenant, enabling realistic and effective testing scenarios.   

 

TDR offers a powerful solution for transferring production like data from the production tenant to the test tenant with the option of depersonalisation feature. It supports the migration of:â€¯ 

  • Master Dataâ€¯ 
  • Transactional Dataâ€¯ 

 

TDR Pre-requisites:â€¯ 

To have a smooth and flawless data transfer during the TDR implementation, the following key prerequisites must be fulfilled at the system level:â€¯ 

  1. Uniform Software Release Across all tenants:â€¯ All Tenants must operate on the same software release configuration to eliminate system discrepancies and ensures reliable data flow.â€¯ 
  2. System Configuration Maintenance: A well-maintained System configuration is essential for system stability there by reduces integration friction.â€¯â€¯ 
  3. Content Version Alignment: All tenants should be in the same content version release to overcome errors during data transfer and could lead to incomplete data mapping.â€¯â€¯ 
  4. Extension Readiness: Ensure all relevant extensions are active and configured with the latest updates by making use of The Handle Your Extensions application.â€¯ 
  5. Clean Production Transport Queue: Make sure that there are no open transports in the development queue to avoid data inconsistency or conflicts.â€¯ 

Note:â€¯ The TDR team will help you to validate and maintain the necessary configurations across tenants, thereby simplifying the process and ensuring the system readiness for TDR onboarding.â€¯ 

 

TDR Process Overview: 

Customers can request TDR service any time during the year based on the Test Data Refresh calendar (kindly refer to the reference link section for the TDR calendar link).  

During the TDR process, the target (Test) tenant application data will be cleared, followed by a full refresh of application data from source (Production) tenant. This ensures the latest high quality and accurate test data availability in the testing tenant to facilitate efficient testing of the developments before moving to production tenant.  

Note: During TDR process, data in target tenant such as system configurations, user data and authorization data will be retained as it is. 

 To ensure data privacy, TDR service offers depersonalization as an optional feature, which ensures sensitive information (Workforce data is out of scope) is anonymized during the data transfer process.â€¯ 

Note:â€¯Depersonalization is a broad and critical topic. Kindly refer to SAP help page to explore depersonalization in detail.â€¯ 

 

Conclusion:â€¯ 

In this Blog, weâ€™ve explored the pre-requisite, scope of TDR. We've also seen how TDR enhances the quality of test data and enriching the test environment and supports a smoother transition to the new test tenant in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. 

We hope this has provided you with a comprehensive and clear understanding of TDR, its benefits, and its role in enabling a smoother transition to the new Test tenant.â€¯

entry.title: The Importance of Primary Finance Settings in SAP Cloud ERP
entry.content:
• This blog is based on version CE2508.
  • The screenshots shown come from an internal SAP test system.

This blog is designed for consultants and customers who are just beginning their journey with SAP Cloud ERP (SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition). Understanding and correctly configuring the Primary Finance Settings is one of the most critical early steps in an implementation project.

 

Why Primary Finance Settings Matter?

At the start of any SAP Cloud ERP implementation, defining the Primary Finance Settings is a fundamental activity. These settings include:

  • Fiscal Year Variant

  • Group Currency

  • Ledgers and Accounting Principles

These initial configurations form the financial backbone of your system. They directly influence all subsequent financial postings, ledgers, and company codes across your organization. Since they are deeply embedded in the system structure, they must be carefully planned and chosen â€” because once saved, they cannot be changed.

 

What are the Primary Finance Settings?
The â€œSpecify Primary Finance Settingsâ€ activity is a one-time configuration in SAP Central Business Configuration (CBC).

Here, you define two crucial values:

  • Fiscal Year Variant (FYV): Determines how your financial year is divided (e.g., calendar or non-calendar year).

  • Group Currency: Ensures consistent and comparable financial reporting across your global entities.

Once these values are saved, they cannot be changed.

The system even displays a clear message:
â€œBe aware that this is a one-time decision which cannot be changed.â€ This highlights just how significant these settings are for your overall ERP landscape.

 

How can I configure the Primary Finance Settings?

Step 1: Selecting Ledgers and Accounting Principles

The number and type of ledgers are defined during the initial scoping phase, and â€” just like the other finance settings â€” cannot be modified later.

During the Define Scope activity, youâ€™ll select the scope items that determine which ledgers are activated:

  • J58 â€“ Activates the Leading Ledger (0L), assigned to the local GAAP at company code level.

  • 1GA â€“ Activates Ledger 2L, corresponding to IFRS accounting principles.

  • 2VA â€“ Activates Ledger 3L, corresponding to US GAAP accounting principles.

Important:
If you choose to work only with one ledger (0L), IFRS and US GAAP principles and their related content will not be available.

For multi-ledger setups, ensure each ledger is assigned to the correct accounting principle. In this blog, I provided detailed guidance: SAP Recommendation: Assignment of Corporate Accounting Principle to Ledger. 

 

Step 2: Defining the Fiscal Year Variant and Group Currency
Within the Specify Primary Finance Settings activity, you select:

  • Fiscal Year Variant (FYV): Defines your companyâ€™s financial reporting structure â€” for instance, whether your fiscal year aligns with the calendar year or follows a custom pattern.

  • Group Currency: A key value that drives consistent financial consolidation and reporting across all entities and ledgers.

 

 

Where Do These Settings Apply?

The Fiscal Year Variant selected during setup is applied to the Leading Ledger and cannot be changed later.

  • Non-leading Ledgers will inherit this setting, but can be adjusted if necessary.

For a full list of supported fiscal year variants, please refer to the SAP Road Map Viewer> SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (3-system landscape) > Explore phase >  accelerator file â€œSupported Fiscal Year Variant.xlsxâ€

The Group Currency applies to all ledgers and company codes in the system.

 

What If You Need to Modify These Settings?

If you realize that your initial configuration was incorrect or needs to be changed, the only option is to request a System Reprovisioning.

However, be aware:

This process can delay your project timeline by more than three weeks.

Please find more details:

  • 3401017 - FAQs about S/4HANA Public Cloud System Reprovisioning
  • Getting started with your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Project - Dodging the System Re-Provisioning Bullets 

To conclude:

The Primary Finance Settings define the financial core of your SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition system.  Because these settings are permanent, always validate your selections carefully before saving. Taking the time to get them right up front will save time on rework and delays later.

 

SAP Help Portal Links:

  • Setting Your Group Currency 
  • Fiscal Year and Fiscal Year Variant 
  • Ledger

 

If you find this information helpful, please remember to give a kudo.

Stay tuned for more tips and insights!

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Security: Integrating Microsoft Sentinel
entry.content:
SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition now integrated with Microsoft Sentinel Solution for SAP 

This blog was co-authored with Martin Pankraz (SAP Security PM, Microsoft) 

In the shared responsibility model for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, most of the security tasks are handled by the cloud service provider â€“ SAP in this case. However, in order to obtain a comprehensive picture of your security posture and for comprehensive threat detection, certain information from the application is also needed. For this, SAP provides APIs for security relevant data - such as the Security Audit Log when weâ€™re speaking about event driven data, but also more static APIs to establish a security dashboard are provided by SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.  

Providing this information, however, is â€“ quite literally â€“ only half of the story. In order to make sense of this information, the receiving solution needs to make sense of the data provided, combine it with relevant data from other systems within the landscape and correlate information with each other. This solution also needs to understand the application that provides the information, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition in this case.  

This is why weâ€™re especially thrilled to announce the Microsoft Sentinel for SAP integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - a cloud-native integration that brings real-time threat detection, investigation, and response to your SAP environment.

Why This Matters  

With Microsoft Sentinel as the receiving end of the security relevant APIs that SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition provides, customers receive a lightweight, scalable, compliant, and AI ready approach to integrate SAP telemetry into their enterprise security operations. 

Our integration delivers exactly that: 

  • Agentless deployment for faster onboarding. 
  • Unified security operations across SAP and non-SAP systems. 
  • Compliance-ready log retention at a fraction of traditional costs. 

What This Release Offers 

1. AI enabled unified Security Operations 

  • Correlate SAP Cloud events with enterprise telemetry in Microsoft Sentinel Solution for SAP and Microsoft Defender XDR ready for Microsoft Security Copilot. 
  • Use prebuilt analytics rules, workbooks, and SOAR playbooks to detect and respond to threats like:  
  • Privilege escalations 
  • Unauthorized configuration changes 
  • Suspicious financial transactions 

2. Compliance-Ready Log Retention 

  • Store SAP logs cost-efficient in Microsoft Sentinel Data Lake for up to 12 years. 
  • Support threat hunting involving SAP on the Sentinel Data lake through KQL jobs. 

Key Benefits 

  • Faster Deployment: Go live in hours, not weeks. 
  • Future-Proof: Built on SAPâ€™s strategic integration approach using APIs. 
  • Security at Scale: Detect and respond to threats across your entire SAP landscape. 

How It Works 

  1. Deploy the Microsoft Sentinel integration package in SAP Integration Suite. 
  2. Configure your Microsoft Sentinel workspace to start ingesting SAP logs. 
  3. Activate prebuilt content for instant visibility and protection. SAP S/4HANA Cloud â†’ SAP Integration Suite â†’ Microsoft Sentinel 

Whatâ€™s Next 

  • General Availability after the current preview phase. 
  • Upcoming enhancements: Expansion of protection scope to additional communication scenarios provided by SAP. 

Getting Started 

Activate SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud - Microsoft Sentinel Integration | Azure portal from the Sentinel Content Hub. Provide your connection details for communication scenario 750 and you are good to go. 

Once deployed, we recommend to check AryaGâ€™s series giving details on how to move to production 

Final Words 

#Kudos to the amazing engineering teams on both sides and our incredible community contributors! 

That's a wrap. Remember: bringing SAP under the protection of your central SIEM isn't just a checkbox - it's essential for comprehensive security and compliance across your entire IT estate. 

Cheers, Patrick & Martin

entry.title: Expiring Price Handling Powered by Joule
entry.content:
The Joule capability "Expiring Price Handling" has been released in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2502.3. This blog introduces this feature in detail, so that you can interact with Joule smoothly and manage expiring prices efficiently. 

 

Overview

You can ask Joule to fetch prices (stored as condition records for pricing in sales in the system) that will expire soon. For expiring prices, Joule can help renew them by extending their validity periods and adjusting the condition amounts or ratios according to your requirements. After you confirm to extend the expiring prices, a price renewal background job will be created. You can also check the progress and result of the price renewal job via Joule.

Figure 1

Please check out the following help document and demo for a glimpse.

    • Help Document: Renew Expiring Prices
    • Demo: Renew Product Prices with Joule

 

Feature in Details

 

Definition of "Expiring Price"

Before using this feature, it's important to understand what qualifies as an "Expiring Price". Joule retrieves prices that expire between the current date and the given date (including both dates) without a successor record. Only records without a successor are considered "Expiring".

  • Case 1 and 2: Prices without a successor --> considered "expiring". 
  • Case 3: Even if its Valid-To date falls between the current date and the given date, it has a successor with a continuous validity period starting right after its Valid-To date --> not considered "expiring".
  • Case 4: Already expired prices --> not considered "expiring".

Figure 2

Note that, this feature only retrieves/renews the prices approaching expiration (meaning still valid for the time being), but cannot fetch/renew the prices which are already expired (Case 4 above).

 

How Are Expiring Prices Renewed?

Instead of updating the original Valid-To date of the expiring price, Joule creates a new continuous validity period for the expiring price (with Valid-From date set to the date one day after the Valid-To date of the expiring price). Optionally, the new validity period could have a new condition amount/ratio. The purpose of this is to keep the existing "Expiring Price" unchanged, but create its successor only.

Do take note that, the new validity being created could possibly overlap with the existing validity that lies in future, such as the Case 2 above. Assume that the gap between the expiring price and its future validity is 9 months long. If we extend the validity period of the expiring price by 1 year, the new validity and existing future validity will overlap for 3 months. In this case, the new validity will overwrite the existing validity during the overlapped period.

 

Always Start from "Show Expiring Prices"

You can activate the "Expiring Price Handling" feature by talking to Joule with phrases like below:

  • "Show me prices for sales organization 1710 that expire before December 31, 2025."
  • "List the prices with condition type PPR0 that are expiring before Dec 31, 2025."
  • "Are there any prices for condition type PPR0 and sales organization 1010 expiring before December 31, 2025?"

Even if you ask Joule to extend the expiring price directly, you will be redirected to show expiring prices, because the extension/renewal could only be performed on the expiring prices already listed in Joule.

Figure 3

Expiration date is a mandatory for querying expiring prices. If the date is not given, Joule will prompt you to provide one, so that it can proceed to search for the expiring prices.

Figure 4

For best results, include at least one of the following filters in your query. Currently, these are the only fields supported as the filter.

  • Condition type
  • Sales organization
  • Distribution channel
  • Product
  • Customer
  • Customer project ID
 
Expiration Urgency Level

The expiring prices will be listed and sorted by urgency:

  • Red:  â‰¤30 days left before expiration
  • Orange:  31~60 days left before expiration
  • Green:  >60 days left before expiration

Figure 5

 

Dynamic Grouping

At the time this blog is being written, Joule can display up to 30 prices per message. If more than 30 expiring prices are found, they will be grouped dynamically,  for example:

  • By condition type + sales org. + urgency level.
  • By condition type + urgency level.
  • By urgency level only.

This ensures the total number of groups is kept â‰¤30.

Figure 6

 

Check Price Renewal Job Log

After clicking "Confirm" to extend prices, a mass creation job will be created in the background to create the new validity periods. You can check progress and result of the renewal job by clicking the "Check Progress" button. The job result is summarized in a card format. You can click "Open in App" to navigate to the "Manage Prices - Sales" app to check the details of the job.

Figure 7

Alternatively, you can also go to "Manage Prices - Sales" app --> click "Monitor Imports and Jobs" at the upper-right corner. --> switch to "Scheduled Jobs" tab. All the previously created jobs are listed, including the mass creation job created from "Manage Prices - Sales" app. Note that the price renewal jobs created via Joule are always named "Price Renewal xxxxxxxxxxxxxx".

Figure 8

 

Limitations

Instability of Resolving Expiration Date

If you ask Joule to show the prices expiring in N months/days, Joule may occasionally resolve the expiration date incorrectly. This can lead to an inaccurate or empty results. This is because the current LLMs do not inherently have awareness of real-time information.

Thus, we recommend providing specific dates to Joule, such as "Show me prices that are going to expire before 31 Dec, 2025" or "List prices due to expire on 31/03/2026".

 

Short Request Timeout

There's a short request timeout (only 15 seconds) imposed by Joule on any API call to backend. If you don't provide any filter criteria, you may encounter a timeout.

Figure 9

Therefore, always include at least one of the supported filters while asking Joule to show the expiring prices.

entry.title: Sorting and aggregation in the SAP Adobe form using scripting language
entry.content:
Sorting and aggregation are common business requirements where users want table outputs to be displayed in a sorted manner and show aggregated amounts based on specific fields, such as invoice number or document number.

In an on-premise SAP system, this is straightforward â€” we can easily manipulate internal table data in ABAP before printing. However, in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, we donâ€™t have access to the ABAP editor to modify internal tables directly. Therefore, such requirements must be handled using form scripting languages like JavaScript or FormCalc within Adobe Forms.


Requirement:
Display only one record per invoice number, even if the invoice contains multiple items. The displayed record should show the total (summed) amount of all items belonging to that invoice.

Assumption:
The internal table containing the invoice data is already extracted and correctly bound to the form context, ensuring that the data is displayed accurately in the output.

Scenario:
To illustrate this case, we are using sample data from the invoice item table (DFKKINVDOC_I), which stores all item-level details for each invoice number.



Now, let's try to generate the PDF and see the output.

Observe that some of the invoice numbers are already sorted but some are not and hence we need to sort the records according to the invoice number. Sorting and aggregation are two steps, hence we will see one by one each step to fulfill the requirements.

Solution:

Sorting and aggregation can easily be achieved using ABAP code in on-premise systems. However, since we are working in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, we need to perform these operations using a scripting language.
In this case, weâ€™ll use JavaScript within the Adobe Form.

Step 1:- Sorting the records first will help us perform the aggregation correctly later.

  • Select the Table in the form layout.

  • Go to the Events tab.

  • Choose the form:ready event.

  • Set the Language to JavaScript.

Step 2:- Write the JavaScript Code for Sorting

Now, write the JavaScript code inside the form:ready event to sort the table records based on the invoice number.

var count = xfa.resolveNodes("GT_INVOICE.DATA[*]").length; // Get the number of records in the table
var table = this.DATA; // Access the Data node of the table
var i = 0; // Iteration for the outer loop
var j = 0; // Iteration for the inner loop
var intialInvoice; // Initial invoice number for which we need to find the duplicate invoice
var duplicateInvoice; // Duplicate invoice number corresponding to the initial invoice

for ( i = 0; i <= count - 1; i++ ){
      intialInvoice = xfa.resolveNode("GT_INVOICE.DATA["+ i +"]").INVDOCNO.rawValue;
      for ( j = i + 1; j <= count - 1; j++ ){
             duplicateInvoice = xfa.resolveNode("GT_INVOICE.DATA["+ j +"]").INVDOCNO.rawValue;
            // if the invoice number is greater, then move the instance( replace the instance of ith index and jth index)
                if ( intialInvoice > duplicateInvoice ) {
                      table.instanceManager.moveInstance(j, i);
                      }
               }
        }

Step 3:- Test the Sorting

Generate the PDF and verify if the data is now sorted by invoice number.

You should observe that the invoice numbers are displayed in sorted order.

Step 4:- Aggregate the Amounts for Each Invoice

The next step is to aggregate the total amount for each invoice.

In the same form:ready event of the GT_INVOICE, add the JavaScript code that compares invoice numbers and sums up the amounts for matching records.
Since the data is already sorted, the loop can safely exit once a non-matching invoice number is found, improving performance.

 

Generate the PDF again and verify that the aggregation works as expected.

You should now see the aggregated amount displayed for each invoice number (refer to the previous screenshot of sorted data for comparison).
The total amount for each invoice appears in the Amount field of the first record for that invoice â€” this happens because our JavaScript logic updates only the first instance.

Step 5:- Display Only One Record per Invoice

Although the aggregation is correct, multiple line items of the same invoice are still visible.
We now need to hide the duplicate invoice entries and display only one record per invoice â€” the one containing the aggregated value.

To achieve this, enhance the JavaScript code in the same form:ready event to suppress duplicate invoice records.
Below is the updated JavaScript code snippet that performs both aggregation and duplicate removal.

 

i = 0;   // reset the value of i to 0
j = 0;   // reset the value of j to 0
var previousInvoice;
var sum = 0;
 
 for ( i = 0; i <= count - 1; i++ ){ 
       initialInvoice = xfa.resolveNode("GT_INVOICE.DATA["+ i +"]").INVDOCNO.rawValue; 
      // initially the previousInvoice is empty and hence we need to put 
      // the invoice number of first iteration of for loop
      if ( previousInvoice == null || previousInvoice == "Empty" || previousInvoice == " "  ){
            previousInvoice = xfa.resolveNode("GT_INVOICE.DATA["+ i +"]").INVDOCNO.rawValue;
       }
      
      if ( ( previousInvoice != null ) && ( previousInvoice == initialInvoice ) ){
                   
          // catch the first iteration of an invoice number from the sorted list
          // counting the number of matching records because we need to hide the other duplicate values
          // only the first iteration of any invoice needs to be retained
          if ( countIteration == '0' ){
               indexValue = i;
          }
          else {
             xfa.resolveNode("GT_INVOICE.DATA["+ i +"]").presence = "hidden";
          }
          countIteration = countIteration + 1;
          
       // add the amounts of matching invoice numbers
       sum = sum + xfa.resolveNode("GT_INVOICE.DATA["+ i +"]").BETRW.rawValue;
      }
      else if( ( previousInvoice != null ) && ( previousInvoice != initialInvoice ) ){
           // here the new invoice number is found and hence the previousInvoice needs to be changed
           // also the sum of amount of earlier invoice number should be updated
           
           xfa.resolveNode("GT_INVOICE.DATA["+ indexValue +"]").BETRW.rawValue = sum;
           
           // now reset the value of sum, indexValue and countIteration
           sum = 0;
           indexValue = 0;
           countIteration = 0;
           
           previousInvoice = xfa.resolveNode("GT_INVOICE.DATA["+ i +"]").INVDOCNO.rawValue;
           
           // Capture the first iteration of the new invoice number
           indexValue = i;
           // Do the sum of the new invoice number
           sum = sum + xfa.resolveNode("GT_INVOICE.DATA["+ indexValue +"]").BETRW.rawValue;
           // increase the iteration counter since the first iteration index has already been captured
           countIteration = countIteration + 1;
           
      }
        
      // check the last iteration of the loop
      // last record should be considered separately
       if ( i == count - 1 ) {
            xfa.resolveNode("GT_INVOICE.DATA["+ indexValue +"]").BETRW.rawValue = sum;
       }
   }

Step 6: Test the Final Output

Generate the PDF once again and verify the output.
You should now see only one record per invoice, each displaying the aggregated amount value.

Please find the attached Javascript code in the text file below for the reference.

Final Result 

The data is now sorted correctly based on the invoice number and also we see only one record of each item with the aggregated amount is being displayed.

Please let me know if you have any suggestions or any other solution for such requirements.

 

Thanks,
Shubham

entry.title: Managing Compliance Register in SAP EHS: Boosting Transparency and Control
entry.content:
In todayâ€™s sustainability driven business environment, organizations are continuously adapting to new regulatory frameworks from environmental permits to occupational health and safety obligations.
With the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release, SAP EHS Compliance Management is designed to centralize this process, ensuring that businesses can track, monitor, and demonstrate compliance across their operations.


Step-by-Step guide:

  1. Maintaining an Entry in the Compliance Register
    1. Confirm master data
      1. Ensure the Location (site / plant) is created and maintained in the system. (The user creating an entry in the compliance register must be assigned as the "Environmental Manager" under the location's "Person Responsible Tab")
      2. Ensure the Regulation / Permit (parent regulation) and its Requirements / Sub-requirements are created in the system.
    2. Open the Manage Compliance Register app (F8632)
      1. Select the relevant Company / Site / Location and establish a link between the available Compliance obligations. This creates an assignment and it appears on the registers list. (Note that Permits can only be linked to the location to which it was originally maintained with)
    3. Maintain Applicability Status for the Requirements and Sub-requirements
      1. Select an assignment and maintain applicability status for compliance and its requirements.
      2. Under "Requirement's" tab, from All Requirements, update the Applicability and Fulfillment Status for all the items that are in scope.  
      3. By default, Applicability will be set as "Not Assessed"
      4. Applicability Status are as below
        1. Applicable - The requirement applies to your location.
        2. Exempted - The requirement can't be implemented and the authorities have exempted your location from having to comply with it.
        3. Not Applicable - The requirement doesn't apply to your location.
        4. Not Assessed - You haven't yet assessed whether the requirement applies to your location, or a reassessment is required.
    4. Set Fulfilment Status at requirement level
      1. Once the Requirement is applicable, it is possible to create and manage "Tasks". After the necessary tasks are completed, maintain the Fulfillment Status by choosing "Set Status"
      2. Fulfillment status are as below
        1. Fulfilled - You assess the requirement as fulfilled, or you've already planned actions to fulfill it.
        2. Fulfilled with Variance - The requirement is fulfilled with acceptable deviations.
        3. Not Assessed - The status of the requirement is undefined. This is the default status for a newly assigned applicable requirement.
        4. Not Fulfilled - The requirement is unfulfilled because either no actions have been taken, or the actions have failed.
      3. Ensure both Applicability and Fulfillment statuses get updated, and If there is an action required for a requirement (e.g., regulation changed or a task failed), mark Action Required = Yes for that requirement and add the remediation note. Once the action is addressed, choose "Clear Action Required" button which immediately set it to No.

         

      4. Go back to Parent compliance, and update the fulfilment status.
      5. Note: The â€œAction Requiredâ€ status auto-updates and triggers an email notification to the responsible person in the following cases:
        1. When a compliance is modified and if the same is already in the register, it changes to â€œYesâ€, indicating review is needed by the Compliance Manager.
        2. If any sub-requirement has Action Required = Yes, the parent compliance also updates to â€œYesâ€.
    5. Change Log Review
      1. Click the â€œView Change Logâ€ button to view all recorded entries, including location creation, compliance creation, assessment updates, and justifications. This ensures an audit-ready register with complete accountability and transparency.
    6. Maintenance of Compliance register
      1. The Environmental manager must ensure that all the compliance in the register are reviewed and up to date.
         

         

  2. Verify in Operational Compliance Overview (F8787)
    1. Open the Operational Compliance Overview app (F8787)
      1. Maintain the necessary filters and choose "Go".
    2. Compliance Overview cards
      1. Compliance Rate : Displays a percentage based on overall fulfilled and fulfilled with variance counts.
        Colour logic:
        â‰¤ 30% â†’ Red
        > 30% and < 60% â†’ Orange
        â‰¥ 60% â†’ Green
      2. Obligation Applicability : Displays the total number of obligations categorised by their applicability status. (i.e., which obligations are applicable across locations).
      3. Obligation Fulfilment : Shows the number of obligations by location and their fulfilment status.
      4. Note: Interacting with any section of the chart will navigate back to the Manage Compliance register app. 

By maintaining a structured digital compliance register and having clear visibility in dashboards:

  • Organizations strengthen their ESG governance structure.
  • It enhances audit readiness, since every regulation, task, and status update is traceable.
  • Most importantly, it bridges the gap between regulatory adherence and sustainability accountability, making compliance measurable and reportable.

The 2508 release is another example of SAPâ€™s commitment to continuously improve the sustainability and compliance landscape.
By leveraging these new functionalities, EHS and sustainability teams can move from reactive reporting to proactive compliance management, ensuring that regulatory requirements are met efficiently and transparently.

This blog is intended for knowledge sharing and aims to help readers better understand and explore SAP Sustainability solutions. I hope it provided valuable insights into the topic discussed. In the upcoming blogs, Iâ€™ll continue sharing key functionalities, practical use cases, and best practices that can help organizations in their sustainability and compliance journey.

Stay tuned for more updates and feel free to share your thoughts or questions in the comments below.

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit: Adapt the XML file to your business needs
entry.content:
When using the staging approach for your data migration, you often face the challenge that the provided XML file contains sheets and columns within the sheets that are not relevant for your business needs.

Did you know that it is possible to adjust the XML files easily?

However, before I go to the possible options, note that you must be careful when deleting, as any change can corrupt the XML structure. There is also no guarantee that such a tailored XML file can still be used after upgrading to a higher release.

After creating a migration project in the SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit using the Migrate Your Data app select Download Template in Action for a specific migration object and choose File Type â†’ XML file.

Note 

The description below is for Microsoft Excel. The procedure may differ when using another spreadsheet program than Microsoft Excel.

Option 1: Delete a non-mandatory sheet

Open the downloaded file and choose Enable Editing button. Select a non-mandatory sheet you want to delete â€“ choose the context menu by clicking on your mouse and choose "Delete".

 Confirm on the follow up pop-up you want to delete.

Proceed in this way with all the non-mandatory sheets that you want to delete.

Note

You can only delete non-mandatory sheets and delete sheets even though the worksheet contains mandatory columns. This is because there is no need to fill the mandatory columns in the sheet with data if the sheet itself is not relevant for your project.

Option 2:  Delete a non-mandatory column within a sheet

First, you need to unprotect the sheet. So, you need to select a sheet where you want to delete one column or more columns â€“ choose the context menu by clicking right on your mouse and select â€œUnprotect Sheetâ€.

Select the column(s) you want to delete â€“ in my example all columns for Tax Calculation Brazil. Choose "Delete".

Note

Alternatively, you can go to File â†’ Info â†’ Protect Workbook area and click on Unprotect for the sheets you want to make changes on.

Save your changes. You can now fill your XML file as usual and load the data into the SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit.

When you upload your data, the tool informs you that the Validation Completed with Warnings.  

To be able to view the messages, choose "Show Messages" you get a list of all messages occurred during Validation.

In this case, warnings are displayed because the fields deleted in the previous steps are missing from the sheet. 

 To load the data into the SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit select your file and transfer the data via Actions â†’ Transfer Data to Staging Tables.

 The instances will be loaded into the SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit staging tables.

You can now proceed with your data migration steps as usual.

 Using CSV files

Like the XML file, you can easily tailor your CSV files  as you only need to use the files for the structures and fields you want to process. Just provide the files for mandatory structures and the structures you need. Within the files you must also only provide the mandatory fields and the fields you need. All the other fields you can remove.  A CSV file has much less administrative data than an XML file. The 100 MB limit is the same, but with tailored CSV files the http-protocol related size limit is not reached that fast as using XML files.

entry.title: Oversized Requirements? Here's how to fix them.
entry.content:
Getting requirement sizing right is an important but less obvious driver of predictable SAP project delivery. It is the art of making requirements neither too big nor too small. This may sound like a detail, but it shapes everything that follows: how releases are planned, how work is owned, and how testing stays traceable. After formulation and classification standards, it is another dimension to properly creating requirements.

Why requirements granularity is important?

Granularity defines how big or small a requirement should be so that it can be delivered, tested, and accepted within a single delivery or release cycle.

On one hand, if requirements are too large, their delivery will stretch across waves. This means that one requirement will not be fully completed and fully tested within one Wave release. That breaks the flow of delivery and the traceability of results.

On the other hand, if requirements are too small, the requirements backlog swells with too many tiny items which adds administration effort and slows down the work.

The golden rule

SAP Activate recommends sizing requirements so they can be fully delivered and tested within a single Wave and inside one Work Package. This makes tracking progress from requirement through configuration to test case much easier.

To keep delivery predictable, adopt a simple rule: One Requirement â†’ One Work Package â†’ One Test Case â†’ One Wave

 Decomposition and Grouping

Use early Explore workshops for iterative refinement which is continuously splitting or regrouping requirements as delivery planning evolves.

If a requirement is too large, decompose it into smaller, independent, testable sub-requirements. Each should deliver a clear, standalone piece of value that can be tested independently. They still can be associated with each other in the same test plan.

If a requirement is too small, group it with other closely related requirements and reformulate them into one coherent requirement delivered as one work package.

The effort pays off: proper sizing makes ownership clear, simpler planning, and complete test traceability from requirement to configuration and testing results.

Iterative refinement

Skipping granularity refinement often leaves oversized requirements that may span two waves. This reduces transparency, complicates test coverage, and makes progress reporting unreliable. Right-sized requirements make governance measurable: every item in the backlog has a clear boundary, a single owner, and a defined success criteria.

Right-sized requirements make governance measurable: every item in the backlog has a clear boundary, a single owner, and a defined success criteria.

Jira practice

Granularity can be managed directly in Jira by defining clear parentâ€“child relationships between Requirements and their Deliverables. This approach keeps ownership, scheduling, and testing transparent.

  • Create each main Requirement as a standard level work item

  • In case of need for a decomposition, add sub-task level work items called Sub-Requirements underneath.

  • Map each Requirement or Sub-Requirement to a single Work Package that will be scheduled in one Wave to preserve traceability.

  • Link every requirement to the corresponding Jira Xray Test Cases that verify acceptance and completion.

 You can visualize the hierarchy using a Jira app such as Structure, to display dependencies and delivery scope clearly

 Whatâ€™s in it for you?

Requirements granularity may sound like a technical detail, but in SAP projects itâ€™s one of the strongest predictors of delivery stability. In simple terms, your project scheduling will be much more reliable.

So, next time before you approve a requirement in your backlog, ask: "Will this fit into one Wave, in one Work Package, tested by one Test Case?" If yes, go to the next requirement.

entry.title: SAP Self-Billing Cockpit Integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud
entry.content:
This guide describes how to set up the integration between the SAP Self-Billing Cockpit and an SAP S/4HANA Cloud system without requiring a cloud connector. It covers both self-billing with automatic posting (SBWAP) and self-billing with invoice creation (SBINV).

Prerequisites

  • You have set up your global account and subaccount.
  • You are assigned the Administrator role for the global account.
  • You are assigned the Security Administrator role for the subaccount to configure authorizations using role collections.

Enabling Communication in SAP S/4HANA Cloud

Creating a Communication User

  1. Log on to the SAP Fiori Launchpad in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud system.
  2. Open the Maintain Communication Users app: Communication Management > Maintain Communication Users.

     

  3. Choose New.
  4. Enter the name, description, and password for the new user.

     

  5. Choose Create.
  6. Record the user name and password for future use. These are required when you create communication arrangements and destinations to SAP S/4HANA Cloud via the SAP BTP cockpit.

Creating a Communication System

  1. Log on to the SAP Fiori Launchpad in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud system.
  2. Launch the Communication Systems app: Communication Management > Communication Systems.

     

  3. Choose New to create a communication system.
  4. On the New Communication System screen, specify the system ID and system name.
  5. Choose Create.
  6. In the Technical Data area, specify:
    • The hostname (the host URL of the self-billing tenant excluding https://, e.g. <subdomain>.eu10.selfbilling.cloud.sap)
    • The logical system name
    • The business system name (your subaccount ID assigned by the SAP BTP cockpit)
    The subdomain is defined when you create a subaccount. Ensure it is identifiable and meaningful for you. You can find your subdomain and subaccount ID in the SAP BTP cockpit.

     

  7. In the Users for Inbound Communication area, add a user:
    • On the New Inbound Communication User screen, enter the communication user name you created earlier, specify the authentication method, and save the settings.
  8. In the Users for Outbound Communication area, add a user:
    • On the New Outbound Communication User screen, enter the technical user name you created earlier.
  9. Save your settings and record the communication system name for future use.

Creating Communication Arrangements

Create communication arrangements for the following scenarios before you proceed.

  • SAP_COM_0367
  • SAP_COM_0008
  • SAP_COM_0106
  • SAP_COM_0120
  • SAP_COM_0087
  • SAP_COM_0158
  • SAP_COM_0159
  • SAP_COM_0360

All these scenarios follow the same configuration procedure; this section uses scenario SAP_COM_0367 as an example.

 

  1. Log on to the SAP Fiori Launchpad in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud system.
  2. Launch the Communication Arrangements app: Communication Management > Communication Arrangements.

     

  3. Choose New.
  4. In New Communication Arrangement, choose SAP_COM_0367 under Scenario, optionally modify the arrangement name, and choose Create.

  5. In the Common Data section, select the communication system you created earlier in Creating a Communication System. The previously created communication user is automatically added to both Inbound and Outbound sections (if applicable).

     

     

  6. If there are any other outbound services, deactivate them and save your settings.

Subscribing to SAP Self-Billing Cockpit

Configuring Destinations

  1. Log on to the SAP BTP cockpit (Cloud Foundry environment) with your registered subaccount.

     

  2. Navigate to Connectivity > Destinations > New Destination to create a new destination for mobile services.

     

  3. In the Destination Configuration wizard, enter:
    • Name: SELFB_DEST_S4HANA
    • URL: Hostname of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud system
    • Authentication: Basic Authentication
    • User: The communication user created in â€œCreating a Communication Userâ€
    • Password: The password of the communication user created earlier
  4. Save your settings and choose Check Connection to verify the connection.

     

Navigate to Service Marketplace in the navigation tree, locate the SAP Self-Billing Cockpit tile, and open it. Choose Create.

 

In the displayed screen, choose an application plan (e.g., default) and proceed as instructed. After the subscription is complete, the status changes to Subscribed.

 

Assigning Role Collections to Users

You can manage role collections as needed. The following table lists the recommended role collections.

Role Collection Role User Remarks

AdminSAP_BR_ADMINISTRATORA technical user on BTPThis role grants the technical user rights to replicate units of measurement and plants data, to check the integration configuration, and to export data.
Billing_ClerkSAP_SELFB_CLERKBilling clerkThis role allows the billing clerk to log in to self-billing apps, make configurations, check document status, and perform processing tasks.
ArchivingSAP_SELFB_ARCHIVINGUser to process archivingThis role allows the user to log in to self-billing apps and perform archiving.
ConfirmationSAP_SELFB_CR_APIA technical user on BTPThis role allows the technical user to receive confirmation messages from SAP S/4HANA Cloud.
TransmissionSAP_SELFB_TR_APIA technical user on BTPThis role allows the technical user to send transmissions to SAP Self-Billing Cockpit.

Create a technical user in your own IDP service.

  1. Log on to the SAP BTP cockpit (Cloud Foundry environment) with your registered subaccount.
  2. Navigate to Security > Role Collections.
  3. Create a role collection, enter a name and a description, and save the settings.
  4. Select the newly created role collection and edit it by adding the corresponding role.
  5. If you want to verify the setup via API, you can assign the Admin role to the technical user and remember its username and password for later use.

     

Creating Other Communication Arrangements

For Scenario SAP_COM_0564

  1. Log on to the SAP Fiori Launchpad in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud system.
  2. Open the Communication Arrangements app: Communication Management > Communication Arrangements.

     

  3. Choose New.
  4. In New Communication Arrangement, choose SAP_COM_0564 under Scenario, optionally modify the arrangement name, and choose Create.

     

  5. In the Common Data section, select the communication system created earlier in Creating a Communication System. The previously created communication user is automatically added to both Inbound and Outbound sections.
  6. In the Outbound Services section, enter the path for the following services:

Service Path Remark

Credit/Debit Memo â€“ Send Confirmation of Creation with Invoice Reference/api-password/selfbilling-confirmation-service/v1/api/CreditDebitMemoConfirmation_In/V2 
Billing Document â€“ Send Confirmation of Fields Updated for Self-Billing/api-password/selfbilling-confirmation-service/v1/api/BillingDocumentUpdateConfirmation_InOnly for SBWAP
Billing Document - Send Confirmation of Simulated Pricing/api-password/selfbilling-confirmation-service/v1/api/BdSimulatePricingConfirmation_In 
Self-Billing Invoice - Send Creation Confirmation/api-password/selfbilling-confirmation-service/v1/api/SelfBillingInvoiceCreationConfirmation_InOnly for SBINV

Note: If you use a custom identity service as an alternative to the SAP ID service, append ?login_hint=%7B%22origin%22%3A%22sap.custom%22%7D to the end of the service path.

The service URL is automatically generated based on the tenant host name and the entered path. For example: <Self-Billing Tenant URL>/api-password/selfbilling-confirmation-service/v1/api/CreditDebitMemoConfirmation_In and <Self-Billing Tenant URL>/api-password/selfbilling-confirmation-service/v1/api/BillingDocumentUpdateConfirmation_In.

 

If there are other outbound services you do not use, deactivate them and save your settings. For example, if you only use SBWAP and no pricing simulation, you can deactivate them as shown below.

 

For Scenario SAP_COM_0002 (SBWAP only)

  1. Log on to the SAP Fiori Launchpad in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud system.
  2. Open the Communication Arrangements app: Communication Management > Communication Arrangements.

     

  3. Choose New.
  4. In New Communication Arrangement, choose SAP_COM_0002 under Scenario, optionally modify the arrangement name, and choose Create.

  5. In the Common Data section, select the communication system created earlier in Creating a Communication System. The communication user is automatically added to Inbound and Outbound sections.
  6. In the Outbound Services section, enter the path for the â€œJournal Entry â€“ Change (Asynchronous) Confirmationâ€ service: /api-password/selfbilling-confirmation-service/v1/api/JournalEntryBulkChangeConfirmation_In
    Note: If you use a custom identity service, append the login hint as described above.
  7. If there are other outbound services, deactivate them and save your settings.

For Scenario SAP_COM_0114

  1. Log on to the SAP Fiori Launchpad in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud system.
  2. Open Communication Arrangements (Communication Management > Communication Arrangements).
  3. Choose New.
  4. Select SAP_COM_0114 under Scenario, optionally modify the arrangement name, and choose Create.
  5. In Common Data, select the communication system created earlier. The communication user is automatically added to Inbound and Outbound sections.
  6. In the Outbound Services section, set the path for the Unit of Measurement â€“ Replicate (A2X) service to: /api-password/selfbilling-core-service/v1/erpintegration/data/UnitOfMeasurementMasterDataReplicationBundleRequest_In
    Note: If you use a custom identity service, append the login hint as described above.
  7. Deactivate all other outbound services.
  8. Under Additional Properties, define Replication Model and save its value (e.g., SB_UOM) for future use.
  9. Navigate to the SAP Fiori Launchpad and launch Replicate by Replication Model. From the dropdown, choose an option beginning with the replication model defined in Step 8 (e.g., SB_UOM_999), then choose Replicate.

For Scenario SAP_COM_0116

  1. Log on to the SAP Fiori Launchpad in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud system.
  2. Open Communication Arrangements (Communication Management > Communication Arrangements).
  3. Choose New.
  4. Select SAP_COM_0116 under Scenario, optionally modify the arrangement name, and choose Create.
  5. In Common Data, select the communication system created earlier. The communication user is automatically added to Inbound and Outbound sections.
  6. In the Outbound Services section, set the path for the Plants â€“ Replicate service to: /api-password/selfbilling-core-service/v1/erpintegration/data/plantsSync
    Note: If you use a custom identity service, append the login hint as described above.
  7. Deactivate all other outbound services.
  8. Under Job Execution Details, define the fields to suit your needs (daily execution is recommended).
  9. Under Additional Properties, define Replication Model and save its value (e.g., SB_PLANT) for future use.
  10. Navigate to the SAP Fiori Launchpad and launch Replicate by Replication Model. From the dropdown, choose an option beginning with the replication model defined in Step 9 (e.g., SB_PLANT_999), then choose Replicate.

Verifying the Setup

After completing all steps, your billing clerk can access SAP Self-Billing Cockpit:

  1. Log on to the SAP BTP cockpit (Cloud Foundry environment) with your registered subaccount.
  2. Navigate to your application plan, then choose Go to Application.
  3. You can now view the apps in SAP Self-Billing Cockpit.

     

You can also verify via API:

  1. In Postman, create a GET request to: https://<subdomain>/api-password/selfbilling-customizing-service/v1/api/check.
  2. Under Authorization, select Basic Auth and enter the username and password of the technical user with the role SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR.
  3. If all checks in odataCheck are 200 OK and there are no items in Configuration Missing in additionalCheck, the setup is correct.

     

Summary

To set up integration between SAP Self-Billing Cockpit and an SAP S/4HANA Cloud system, we first need to enable communication in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud system and then subscribe to an application plan of SAP Self-Billing Cockpit via the SAP BTP cockpit.
